pros: Working here is a great option for both new nurses and experienced nurses. The pay scale at this hospital is very solid with limitless opportunities for bonus pay. The leadership I work under are professional and understanding. The hospital cares about its staff and their safety. Being a hospital that is roughly 118 inpatient beds it's not a sprawling and confusing campus compared to other hospitals. That also means that you see the same faces on a regular basis and can form some strong bonds with colleagues.
cons: It is not a high level trauma center, so you won't normally be caring for crash, burn, GSW victims. If you are in the ED you will see some wild stuff, but generally high level trauma victims are transferred to Methodist. The former pro of seeing the same faces can also be a con because if drama starts it can spread pretty quickly considering everyone knows someone on every unit. It's not a huge con given that this is a frequent occurrence in workplaces in any industry, if you're not into gossip and drama then just detach from those conversations and you're pretty easily out of it.

job_title: RN Clinical Coordinator in Indianapolis, IN
pros: - Bedside staff and nurses are kind and committed to patients despite few resources - There are a few nursing managers who care about their direct reports - Clinical education is doing their best - Lots of potential for the community and for caregivers if given the right visionary leadership support - Benefits were good, they have their own private insurance, Community Health Direct
cons: - Witnessed multiple racist remarks and discrimination toward brown and Black caregivers by management. - Witnessed and intervened abuse by Project Search caregiver toward one of the young adults in the program. Not okay! - Personally experienced multiple incidents of ableism and disability discrimination. This ultimately was the cause of me leaving Community. - There is hostility between providers and nursing staff. Many medical providers refuse to support or respect nurse practitioners and refer to them as "midlevels." - There is no nursing clinical ladder to advance in position or pay as you grow in your expertise or complete formal education. Opportunities are given by association, not by merit. - Executive team lacks vision and consistency. Leadership style is chaotic and employs a new "leadership" fad seemingly every year (See me as a person, I2E2, A3 process planning, AEP, DiSC assessments, etc). Way too many resources sunk into these fads when leadership should be focused on the staffing crisis they've created. - HR sincerely does not understand or respect Millennial or Gen Z staff. This is reflected in their lower pay compared to the rest of the greater metro area and their lack of cultivating and retaining talent. - Zero retention efforts and no offboarding support. I carried insurance for my family and had to call or message HR for nearly two weeks to get the letter I needed for our insurance coverage to be transferred. I did not receive the letter until one week after my last day.

pros: I work at the South campus on the med/surg units. My co-workers are fabulous (for the most part) Everyone works as a team to make sure patients are well cared for and safe. The team attitude comes from a strong passion to do our best, not for our bosses, but for our patients. Our patients come first and we support each other to see the patients get and stay healthy.
cons: Management only looks out for themselves. They will gossip about you to other people, your personal life and your privacy are not important. Patient care comes second to their menial tasks. They will not help an overwhelmed nurse, but will instead scold her for not working harder. They will do what they can to keep their job, even if that means throwing you under the bus. My holiday schedule was changed two weeks before the holiday and instead of recognizing that I may have plans, I was forced to either come in or face a write-up. Management does not recognize good behavior in any way. The only time you see or hear from management is when you have done something wrong. The communication 'pipeline' is weak. The director gets information and she relies on 'word-of-mouth' to ensure it reached all 100+ employees she oversees.

pros: Flexible work schedule for employees

review_title: Great work environment, but bad health insurance and horrible security and workplace safety
pros: Great upper management and leadership. Small chain of command compared to bigger companies. More of a “family” environment at work. Employees smile at work and genuinely seem happy. Pay is good. Good PTO
cons: They do not take security/gun threats seriously. They DO NOT have a zero tolerance pt harassment/violent threat/gun threat policy. Health insurance gets worse with less coverage and higher premiums each year. They do not “take care of their own” when an employee is sick. They do not allow enough call in days a year. this is especially true for parents who may need off work because their kids may be sick.

pros: such an amazing working environment
cons: the work life balance is tough

review_title: Very healthy experience, love the people I work with.
pros:
I am very happy to be a part of Community. My supervisor has encouraged me to seek additional experience so that my resume (as well as my paycheck) can grow. In two years I have been promoted three times. Each promotion was prompted by my supervisor's desire to see my work acknowledged.
The people I encounter on a daily basis are the nicest you will ever meet. I have had some family issues arise during my time with them and my supervisor and co-workers have stood by me. This kind of environment is the healthiest I have ever been a part of.
The benefits are great. Medical is probably pretty standard, but they do offer a wide range of side benefits as well. There is a program called Bridges to Weight Management for those who would like to lose weight in a healthy manner. You work with a physician, a therapist, a dietician and a fitness specialist. No extra cost to you either!
I especially enjoy the discounts offered to employees: tickets to sporting events, symphonies, amusement parks etc. can be gotten cheaper through Community. A great way to keep the workers' morale boosted.
cons: Can not think of any cons.

job_title: School Based Therapist in Indianapolis, IN
pros: Great CEO, good pay, good benefits, worked at excellent school system , great co-workers overall who care about their clients and just want to focus on them and provide good care
cons:
Some managers are poorly trained with little to no experience in holding people accountable and/or dealing with ethical issues  
Management wants to be “ liked”
 versus “respected” and can’t stand up for what is right

Major focus on productivity and “well worded (vs accurate) documentation” for reimbursement instead of the best needs of the client/kids/families 
Honest feedback is not encouraged and promotes an environment of “tell the boss what they want to hear”

Poor training among members of management regarding trauma informed care



Lack of trust in management as their views change from day to day based on who is in the room/no consistency from day to day

pros: There are some really, really  good people who work there, and it is a family-like environment There has been a lot of emphasis in recent years on improving the culture and a great focus on the patient experience, which I think has been a good thing.
cons:
The family-like environment is not without its share of family disfunction. Seems there is a reorganization of some kind every 6-9 months, which has you wonder just how stable the organization really is or whether senior management knows what they're doing.
For all the emphasis put on culture and patients, it can be pretty inconsistent how all of that is implemented. 
Especially being both an employee there AND a patient, you know all the things that people are being trained to say and do to patients and then when you actually are there as a patient and the people DON'T do those things you know they are supposed to, that's really frustrating.

review_title: Lack of respect for the older worker
pros: It was close to where I live and relatively safe environment but.........
cons: The place doesn't have any respect for their older, long time employees and they began laying off these people under the guise of "phased retirement" whatever that means.  It means that if you are close to 62 and you've been there enough time to get your traditional pension then you were phased into retire whether you wanted to or not.

review_title: RN Clinical Education, 5 years with Community
pros: Community believes in investing in their people to help them reach their highest potential. The network has partnership with area universities, a wonderful tuition reimbursement, and student externship programs. The network stands by the name Community. The employees, management and corporate staff support community needs with their 360 program and push for all to give to those in need. The network has also been supportive with other health networks to build in their need to improve technology and patient care.
cons: There is an unfortunate level of tolerance for badly behaved managers from HR. The network states zero tolerance for workplace violence and bullying, but, managers seem to be ok to break the standards within this. This should apply equally to all employees at every level.

review_title: They could be a much better employer
pros: Great co-workers, average pay. They do offer employer funded HRA/HSA, but ONLY if you go to a Community Health Network provider...translation, you can use these funds ONLY if you give it back to us!
cons: HORRIBLE insurance benefits! As a hospital system, you would think it would be better. Nearly all insurances have lower deductibles and out-of-pocket cost, and obtaining authorizations is very challenging, you will be on hold forever. Management shows favoritism to under-performing employees and the "pretty people". Many openings are filled by promoting friends & family who are unqualified. Inconsistent instructs are given, so employees doing the same work are completing tasks differently and often incompletely.

review_title: Top down all the way, is the new way
pros:
Remnants of family culture can still be found
Pay is decent
Patients First is largely true
cons:
VP turnover is constant, and many of the newer ones are more about relationship than competency
Rahm Emmanuel would be proud. They have used COVID crisis to implement executive wish lists of initiatives to their hearts delight
Have no regard to working conditions of mgmt team members - have taken a disposable mentality. how many network wide physician exec’s do you really need? 
Mgmt systems are reflective of the culture; too many of them, duplicative, hastily launched, subtracted and added all the time, w little support to understand the expectations, and uses, little lone beat practices.

pros:
Love this Network! Growing fast in the right direction. Awesome culture. Leadership is genuine and acts with integrity.  
Shift differentials are great, by far best in area.  Night shift is base+$4.25 after 11p. Weekends are additional 20% of base. Match up to 6% on 401k. My unit is well staffed. Cannot speak for all units, but mine is well staffed.

-Not for me, but some like to work where there are lots of extra shifts to pick up. We are well staffed so there aren't a ton.
-Pay strictly based on experience, not education.

-Community pays sign on bonuses instead of retention bonuses to RN.  Most nurses who get bonus only stay for minimum contract requirement.
